column1: The Egyptian Air Force (EAF) (Arabic: القوات الجوية المصرية‎
column2: El Qūwāt El Gawīyä El Maṣrīya)
column3: is the aviation branch of the Egyptian Armed Forces
column4: is responsible for all airborne defence missions and operates all military aircraft
column5: including those used in support of the Egyptian Army
column6: Egyptian Navy and the Egyptian Air Defense Forces.  The latter was created as a separate command in the 1970s and it coordinates with the Air Force to integrate air and ground-based air defense operations. The EAF is headed by an Air Marshal (Lieutenant General equivalent).  Currently
column7: the commander of the Egyptian Air Force is Air Marshal Mohamed Abbas. The force's motto is 'Higher and higher for the sake of glory' (Arabic: إلى العلا في سبيل المجد‎

column1: The Egyptian Army Air Service was formed in 1932
column2: and became an independent air force in 1937. It had little involvement in the Second World War. From 1948 to 1973 it took part
column3: with generally mediocre results
column4: in four separate wars with Israel
column5: as well as the quasi-War of Attrition. It also supported the Egyptian Army during the North Yemen Civil War and the Libyan–Egyptian War of 1977.  From 1977 to 2011 it saw virtually no combat
column6: but has participated in numerous exercises
column7: including Operation Bright Star. Since 1992 the EAF has also provided aviation support for the police and other national security organizations engaged in the war against terrorism. In recent years the Air Force has acted in the Sinai insurgency
column8: the Second Libyan Civil War and the Intervention in the Yemen.

column1: The EAF primary role is the air defence of the nation
column2: with secondary tasks of strike and army support operations. The EAF provides official government transport and carries out international search-and- rescue operations in the desert
column3: the Mediterranean Sea
column4: and the Red Sea.

column1: In 2014 the IISS estimated the total active manpower of the Egyptian Air Force at approximately 30
column2: 000 personnel
column3: including 10
column4: 000 conscripts
column5: with reserves of 20
column6: 000 personnel. This contrasts with an estimate of some 35
column8: with most aircrew being long-term professionals

column2: the Parliament of Egypt proposed the creation of an Egyptian Air Force. The Egyptian ministry of war announced that it needed volunteers for the new arm to become the first four Egyptian military pilots. Over 200 Egyptian officers volunteered
column3: but in the end only three succeeded in passing strict medical tests and technical examinations.

column1: These three went to No. 4 Flying Training School RAF at RAF Station Abu Sueir near the Suez Canal
column2: where they were trained on a variety of aircraft. After graduation
column3: they traveled to the United Kingdom for specialised training.

column2: the King of Egypt and Sudan
column3: Fuad I announced the creation of the Egyptian Army Air Force (EAAF). On 27 May 1931 the Egyptian Council of Ministers approved the purchase of five aircraft and the building of an airfield at Almaza (Cairo) with a budget of 50
column4: 000 pounds. The aircraft chosen was the British de Havilland Gipsy Moth trainer
column5: the five modified aircraft were flown from England to Egypt and on arrival in May 1932 the air force was founded and the Almaza airfield was formally opened.

column1: The first commander of the EAAF was Squadron Leader Victor Hubert Tait RAF
column2: a Canadian
column3: former Senior Air Advisor on the British Military Mission in Egypt. Tait selected staff
column4: weapons and initiated building a number of airfields. In 1934 the British government provided ten Avro 626 aircraft
column5: which were the first real Egyptian military planes. A further 17 626s together with Hawker Audaxes for army cooperation and close support and Avro Ansons for VIP work followed shortly afterward.

column1: In 1937 the Egyptian Army Air Force was separated from the Army Command and became an independent branch named the Royal Egyptian Air Force (REAF). New stations were built in the Suez Canal Zone
column2: and the Western Desert.

column1: During 1938 the REAF received two squadrons (Nos 2 and 5) of Gloster Gladiator biplane fighters and No. 1 Squadron of then-modern Westland Lysander reconnaissance aircraft
column2: Egypt was the last state to use the Lysander in action
column3: during the 1948 Arab–Israeli War.

column1: As the Egyptian border was threatened by an Italian and German invasion during the Second World War
column2: the Royal Air Force established more airfields in Egypt.  The Royal Egyptian Air Force was sometimes treated as a part of the Royal Air Force
column3: at other times a strict policy of neutrality was followed as Egypt maintained its official neutrality until very late in the war. As a result
column4: few additional aircraft were supplied by Britain
column5: however the arm did receive its first modern fighters
column6: Hawker Hurricanes and a small number of Curtiss P-40 Tomahawks. In the immediate post-war period
column8: including a large number of Supermarine Spitfire Mk.IXs were acquired.

column1: A 1946 order of battle for the Air Force can be found in Jane's Fighting Aircraft of World War II
column2: listing Nos 1

column1: Following the British withdrawal from the British Protectorate of Palestine and the establishment of the State of Israel on 14 May 1948
column2: Egyptian forces crossed into Palestine as part of a wider Arab League military coalition in support of the Palestinians against the Israelis.  The Egyptian Air Force contribution included the Short Stirling bomber
column3: Douglas C-47 Dakotas performing as light bombers and Spitfires.

column1: Two Israeli aircraft were shot down and on 22 May 1948
column2: Egyptian Spitfires attacked the RAF Ramat David airfield
column3: believing that it had already been taken over by Israeli forces. The first raid surprised the British
column4: and resulted in the destruction of several RAF aircraft on the ground
column5: and the deaths of four airmen. The British were uncertain whether the attacking Spitfires had come from Arab or Israeli forces.  When second and third raids followed shortly afterwards
column6: the British were ready and the entire Egyptian force was shot down – the last aircraft being baited for some time as the RAF pilots attempted to get a close look at its markings.

column1: Relations with Britain were soon restored and the official state of war with Israel ensured that arms purchases continued.  New Spitfire Mk. 22s were purchased to replace the earlier models. In late 1949
column2: Egypt received its first jet fighter
column3: the British Gloster Meteor F4 and shortly after de Havilland Vampire FB5s.

column2: Egypt made an agreement to buy heavy arms from Czechoslovakia
column3: culminating four years of attempts. The Egyptian Government was determined to move away from reliance on British armaments. 1951 discussions had included 60–100 Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-15 fighters. Initial Soviet bloc deliveries included the MiG-15s
column4: Ilyushin Il-28 bombers
column5: Ilyushin Il-14 transports
column6: and Yak-11 trainers. Instructors from Czechoslovakia accompanied these aircraft.  Egypt also began manufacturing its own Czechoslovak-designed Gomhouria Bü 181 Bestmann primary trainers at this time

column1: After the Egyptian Government's nationalisation of the Suez Canal in 1956
column2: Egypt was attacked by Israel
column3: France
column4: and the United Kingdom in what came to be known as the Suez Crisis ("Tripartite Aggression" in Egypt). Heavy losses were sustained by the Egyptian side.  After U.S. pressure
column5: the French and British withdrew their forces after seizing the city of Suez. The war also forced the EAF to begin rebuilding without British help.

column2: Egypt merged with Syria to form the United Arab Republic
column3: and the previously separate Egyptian and Syrian forces were combined as the United Arab Republic Air Force. Though Syria left the union in 1961
column4: Egypt continued to use the union's official name until 1971
column5: including for its air force.

column1: One of the first Egyptian Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-19 units was the 15th Air Brigade
column2: consisting of Nos 20 and 21 Squadrons
column3: which became operational at Fayid with a forward location at Milayz in the early 1960s.By the mid-1960s
column4: British aircraft had been replaced completely by Soviet hardware. The Soviet Union became the principal supplier of the EAF
column5: and many other Arab states. This allowed the EAF to greatly modernise and boost its combat effectiveness. The MiG-21 Fishbed arrived in the early 1960s
column6: bringing with it a Mach 2 capability. The MiG-21 would remain Egypt's primary fighter for the next two decades. The EAF also began flying the Sukhoi Su-7 fighter/bomber in the mid-1960s. By 1966
column8: with its primary base at Cairo West Air Base
column9: was operating three squadrons of Tupolev Tu-16 "Badgers": No. 34 and 36 Squadrons with bomber variants
column10: and No. 95 Squadron equipped with the Tu-16KS' that could carry AS-1 Kennel air-to-surface missiles. In 1967

column1: Egypt also took over the Helwan HA-300 from Spain as its first supersonic aircraft. It never went beyond three prototypes and initial test flights
column2: then was abandoned due to high costs and political factors. The German designers involved had to leave Egypt after death threats from the Israeli intelligence agency Mossad.

column1: The Yemeni Royalist side received support from Saudi Arabia and Jordan
column2: while the Yemeni Republicans were supported by Egypt.  The fighting was fierce
column3: featuring heavy urban combat as well as battles in the countryside.  Both foreign irregular and conventional forces were also involved.

column2: the Yemen War was an opportunity for Israel. It stagnated Egyptian military plans for the reinforcement of Sinai
column3: by shifting the Egyptian military focus to another theater of operation.  Egyptian historian Mohammed Heikal writes that Israel provided arms shipments and also cultivated relationships with hundreds of European mercenaries fighting for the Royalists in Yemen. Israel established a covert air-supply bridge from Djibouti to North Yemen. The war also gave the Israelis the opportunity to assess Egyptian combat tactics and adaptability.

column1: Egyptian air and naval forces began bombing and shelling raids in the Saudi southwestern city of Najran and the coastal town of Jizan
column2: which were staging points for royalist forces. In response
column3: the Saudis purchased British Thunderbird (missile) surface-to-air missiles and developed their King Khalid airfield near Khamis Mushait. Riyadh also attempted to convince the United States to respond on its behalf. In Operation Hard Surface
column4: President Kennedy sent jet fighters and bombers to Dhahran Air Base from May 1963
column5: demonstrating to Egypt the seriousness of his commitment to defending U.S. interests in Saudi Arabia.

column1: In the 1967 Six-Day War the EAF's combat capacity was severely damaged after the Israeli Air Force destroyed its air bases in a preemptive strike codenamed Operation Focus.  During the last four days the EAF conducted only 150 sorties against Israeli units throughout the Sinai. After the war
column2: the Soviet Union replenished EAF stocks
column3: sending large numbers of aircraft and advisors to Egypt to revitalise the EAF.

column1: The EAF's first air-to-air victory is claimed by Mig-21 pilot Nabil Shoukry against a Mirage IIICJ fighter over Inchas air base two hours following the first Israeli strike.On 8 June 1967
column2: a pair of Egyptian MiG-21s engaged a pair of Mirage IIIs over the Sinai.  In the ensuing dogfight
column3: the EAF's 1st Lt Fakhry El-Ashmawy managed to down one of the Mirage fighters while the second Mirage crashed from fuel exhaustion.Initial Egyptian claims were even more inflated
column4: but were later reduced to 72 Israeli aircraft destroyed. The IDF/AF admitted 45 losses on all fronts
column5: while outside observers put the figure between 55 and 60.  Years later
column6: unofficial Israelis sources admitted ten IDF/AF aircraft downed in air combat on all fronts.  Independent sources put this figure at 11
column7: plus another resulting in fuel exhaustion. In fact
column8: several Israeli aircraft reportedly downed by ground fire probably fell to Egyptian fighters.

column2: Nigeria received support from Egypt
column3: as Abdel Nasser sent Egyptian pilots. Pilots were provided to fly the aircraft procured by the Soviet Union
column4: air force Mikoyan MiG-17 fighters and Ilyushin Il-28 bombers. The Egyptian conscripts frequently attacked civilian rather than military targets
column5: bombing numerous Red Cross shelters.

column1: The years between 1967 and 1970 involved a prolonged campaign of attrition against Israel. The EAF went through a massive construction program to build new air bases in order to increase its survivability. During this period Egypt also received replacements for losses it suffered during the Six Day War. The EAF was the first branch of the Egyptian armed forces to achieve full combat readiness.

column2: six Israeli Mirage III fighters violated Egyptian airspace and orders were given for two formations each consisted of two MiG-21 fighters to intercept
column3: another formation of 2 MiGs piloted by Major Fawzy Salama & Lieutenant Medhat Zaki was ready in West Cairo airbase. Indeed
column4: the formation took off
column5: but for protecting the airbase rather than supporting the interception.

column1: During the initial surprise air attack of the Yom Kippur War
column2: over 220 EAF aircraft took part. Unlike their Syrian counterparts
column3: EAF aircraft evaded Israeli radars by flying below detection height. EAF aircraft were held in reserve after that point
column4: mainly concentrating on airfield defence in conjunction with the SA-3 'Goa'
column5: while the more mobile SA-6 'Gainful' protected Egyptian forces at low and medium level
column6: aided by the ZSU-23-4SP and shoulder-held SA-7 SAMs.

column2: the EAF conducted offensive sorties from time to time. The Su-7BM was used for quick strafe attacks on Israeli columns and the Mirage IIIE (sometimes confused with the Mirage 5)
column3: donated by Libya
column4: carried out long-range attacks deep inside Sinai at Bir Gifgafa.

column2: when Israeli armoured forces used a gap between the two Egyptian armies to cross the Suez Canal (Operation Stouthearted Men)
column3: they destroyed several Egyptian SAM sites
column4: forcing the EAF into battle against the IAF. The EAF claimed victories and continued to contest IAF operations
column5: while also launching attacks on Israeli ground forces on the East Bank of the Suez Canal. In most of these engagements
column6: Egyptian MiG-21s (of all types) challenged Israeli Mirage IIICJs or Neshers.The IAF did not operate freely and did not have complete air supremacy it enjoyed during the previous conflict
column7: the 1967 war. Egyptian MiGs were used with better efficiency than before which included the tactics and lessons learned from the 1967 war.It was during this war that the EAF applied the lessons it earlier learnt from the Israelis. A 32-year-old deputy MiG-21 regiment commander who has been flying since he was 15 recalls:

column1: During the war of attrition, the Israeli air force had a favorite ambush tactic
column2: he told Aviation Week and Space Technology. "They would penetrate with two aircraft at medium altitude where they would be quickly picked up by radar
column3: We would scramble four or eight to attack them. But they had another dozen fighters trailing at extremely low altitude below radar coverage. As we climbed to the attack they would zoom up behind and surprise us. My regiment lost MiGs to this ambush tactic three times. But we learned the lesson and practiced the same tactics. In the final fights over Deversoir
column4: we ambushed some Mirages the same way
column5: and my own 'finger four' formation shot down four Mirages with the loss of one MiG."The Egyptian Air Force commander during the war was then-Air Marshal Hosni Mubarak. On 14 October 1973 one of many Egyptian/Israeli air engagements took place. Initial Egyptian reports that 15 Israeli aircraft had been destroyed. on the day of "Air battle of Mansoura". Later on
column6: the Egyptian government changed the country's "Air Force Day" from 2 November to 14 October
column7: to commemorate the Mansourah air battle. Mubarak was even promoted and feted as a national hero after the war
column8: It was estimated that over 2200 take offs were done by the Egyptian Air Force throughout the war that included dogfighting and ground attacks.

column1: During the Shaba I crisis in Zaire on 1977
column2: Egyptian Air Force provided 50 pilots and technicians
column3: which operated Mirage jets for the Zairian Air Force.

column2: there were some skirmishes between Libyan and Egyptian fighters. In one instance
column3: two Libyan Air Force MiG-23MS engaged two EAF MiG-21MFs that had been upgraded to carry Western weaponry. The Libyan pilots made the mistake of trying to manoeuvre with the more nimble Egyptian fighters
column4: and one MiG-23MS was shot down by EAF Maj. Sal Mohammad
column5: while the other Libyan aircraft used its speed advantage to escape.

column1: From 1980 the EAF was involved in the joint U.S.-Egyptian biannual Exercise Bright Star.

The Egyptian Air Force operated on a large scale during the Sinai insurgency which commenced in 2011. AH-64 Apache helicopters and F-16 jet fighters bombed numerous militant targets on almost a daily basis.

During the Second Libyan Civil War there were conflicting reports that Egyptian warplanes bombed Islamist militias in support of the government based in Tobruk. The foreign ministry denied any involvement in the conflict although unnamed Egyptian military officials claimed otherwise. Egypt tightened security on Libyan border following mysterious air strikes. Egyptian forces near the Libyan border have been put on high alert following air strikes on 2016 Jan 10 from unidentified fighter jets inside Libya. The fighter jets struck Islamic State of Iraq and Levant (ISIL) targets inside Libya
column2: according to news reports. The Libyan coastal city of Sirte has served as ISIL's capital in North Africa since the terror group seized the city last summer.After receiving three MiG-21MFs and three Mi-8s from Egypt just half a year ago
column3: it appears the Libyan Air Force is now further strengthened by two MiG-21MFs from the same source. The former EAF mounts are a welcome addition to the under-equipped Libyan Air Force
column4: which is currently waging a war against Libya Dawn
column5: Ansar al-Sharia and even the Islamic State
column6: the latter centered around the Libyan city of Derna.On 6 March 2016
column7: Egypt and France began on Sunday a joint military exercise termed as the "Ramses-2016" in the coastal city of Alexandria along the Mediterranean. The French nuclear-powered aircraft carrier Charles de Gaulle is steaming through the Red Sea on its way to the Mediterranean via the Suez Canal for joint maneuvers with the Egyptian air force and navy in preparation for a reduced coalition offensive against Islamic State's deepening grip on Libya.

column1: The February 2015 Egyptian airstrikes in Libya against Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) positions in Libya took place on 16 February 2015
column2: and were triggered by a video released by ISIL in Libya a day earlier
column3: depicting the beheading of 21 Coptic Christians from Egypt.

column2: the Egyptian Air Force responded with airstrikes against ISIL training camps and weapons stockpiles in retaliation for the killings. Warplanes acting under orders from the Libyan government also struck targets in Derna
column3: reportedly in coordination with Egypt. It is believed that more than eight EAF f-16 jet fighters were used for the strikes
column4: including the newly joined "block 52" versions.

column1: The air strikes had allegedly killed up to 81 ISIL militants
column2: including three of the leadership
column3: in the coastal cities of Derna and Sirte. Libyan media reported that at least 35 more Egyptians had been rounded up by ISIL in retaliation for the air raids.

column1: Egyptian Air Forces are participating in a Saudi-led joint regional military operation to halt the advance of Shia Houthi rebels in Yemen
column2: Egypt's presidency announced on 2015 March 25 in a statement. the Egyptian Air Force participated in airstrikes against Houthis in Yemen.Egypt's military participation "through elements of the Egyptian air and navy forces" aims to support the Saudi-led regional coalition to restore stability in Yemen "under legitimate leadership"
column3: according to the Egyptian presidency's statement.The Egyptian air force supported pro-government forces when they attacked Al Anad Air Base in the south of Yemen. "EAF and paratroopers aerial supported Yemeni ground forces who have now seized the military base killing scores of Houthi rebels".

column1: In retaliation for an ISIL attack on a Coptic bus in Minya
column2: the Egyptian Air Force conducted six air strikes against terror camps in Libya as reported by state television.

column1: Silver Stars is the Egyptian Air Force aerobatic display team flying 10 K-8E Karakorum jet trainer aircraft painted in white
column2: red and black colors. All planes are equipped with red
column3: white and black smoke generators. During the shows
column4: the Silver Stars performs eight different formations along with several single aircraft passes. Aircraft #6325 (Star 1) carries the name "Sharaf" after the team leader. Another team's planes also carried the pilots names painted at the K-8 nose. All pilots are flying instructors at the Egyptian Air force Academy based in Belbeis Airport.

column1: The Egyptian Air Force demonstration team "The Silver Stars" was formed in the mid of 1974 to participate at "October War" anniversary. Pilots of the team were flying instructors at the Air force College and flew four L-29 planes painted in dark green and brown and yellow – standard color scheme. In 1984
column2: the Sliver Stars aerobatic team switched to six Alpha Jet training airplanes. In the following year
column3: team's planes became nine.

column2: the team made the switch to the K-8E Karakorum trainer and from 2005 was led by Group Captain Mostafa Fathi.
the team is now flying ten aircraft – nine plus one solo.

column1: The Camp David Accords caused a gradual change in the overall composition of the EAF. The EAF began to rely more on US
column2: French and in some cases on Chinese aircraft.

column1: The addition of these aircraft from multiple sources along with the ones already in the EAF inventory caused increasing serviceability problems. In 1982
column2: the EAF began receiving General Dynamics F-16 Fighting Falcon fighters under the Peace Vector Program. Turkish Aerospace / TUSAS produced 46 F-16s for the Egyptian Air Force between 1993 and 1995 under the agreement signed between the Governments of Turkey and the Arab Republic of Egypt.. As of 2015
column3: the EAF received a total of 220 F-16s. 18 aircraft were lost in accidents and 7 F-16A/Bs were grounded.

column1: These grounded F-16A/Bs were later overhauled
column2: upgraded and returned to active service
column3: additional F-16s were acquired to replace those lost. In 1986
column4: the EAF received the French Mirage 2000 fighters
column5: one was lost in a training accident. Egypt also license-built Alphajets
column6: Tucano airplanes and Westland Gazelle helicopters.

column1: In 1987 the E-2C Hawkeye Airborne Early Warning (AEW) entered service and was upgraded with advanced AN/APS-145 radars. The EAF also upgraded its F-16 fighters to C/D standard that enabled them to fire the AGM-84 Harpoon anti-ship missile.
The EAF currently operates 46 AH-64 Apache attack helicopters 36 of which were initially delivered as the AH-64A variant but were later upgraded to AH-64D standard. On 22 May 2009
column2: Egypt requested the purchase of 36 Apache Arrowhead sensor systems as part of an order for 12 Block II AH-64D Apache helicopters. The number was later reduced to 10 Helicopters. 74 Grob G-115's and 120 K-8 Karakorum trainers were also ordered.

column1: Egypt made several deals with Ukrainian companies for the modernization of its old MiG-21 fleet but these deals were not implemented and all old mig21 were put out of service .

column2: the EAF ordered 20 Lockheed Martin F-16C/D Block 52 aircraft. The contract was set to complete in 2013 and included 16 single-seat F-16C and four twin-seat F-16D aircraft.

the US Defense Department awarded a major contract to facilitate the procurement of F-16s by the EAF. The Pentagon selected American International Contractors for a $66.6 million contract to upgrade infrastructure for Egypt's order of 20 F-16 Block 52 aircraft
column3: estimated at $2.2 billion. On 24 July 2013
column4: the U.S. announced it would halt deliveries of the F-16s in response to the 2013 Egyptian coup d'état. In March 2015 the US announced the resumption of the deliveries of the F-16s
column5: the last of which was delivered in October 2015.On 16 February 2015
column6: Egypt became the Rafale's first international customer when it officially ordered 24 Rafales
column7: as part of a larger deal (including a FREMM multipurpose frigate and a supply of missiles) worth US$5.9 billion (€5.2 billion). In July 2015
column9: marking the acceptance by Egypt of its first 3 Rafales
column10: was held at the Dassault Aviation flight test center in Istres. In January 2016
column11: Egypt received three more Rafale fighters
column12: raising the number of Rafales in service to six. All six aircraft are two-seat models and were diverted from delivery to the French Air Force; Egypt's total 24-plane order is for 8 single-seat models and 16 two-seaters.In April 2014
column13: it was reported that Egypt plans to order 24 MiG-35 fighters as part of an arms deal. MiG head Sergei Korotkov said at the 2015 Aero India exposition they will provide the fighters if Egypt orders them and are ready to negotiate. Russia agreed on a contract with Egypt for 46 MiG-29M/M2 fighters and is expected to be worth up to $2 billion. Russia plans to supply the Egyptian MiG-29M/M2s with 40 high precision targeting pods. Deliveries would begin in 2016.Russia and Egypt signed a contract for delivery of 50 Ka-52 helicopters. The Ka-52 will be equipped with the new OES-52 targeting system allowing it to launch Vikhr and Ataka anti-tank missiles using laser target direction systems. The execution of the contract will start in 2016 until 2018.SAGEM and AOI-Aircraft Factory have signed a collaboration agreement concerning the Patroller UAV. AOI-Aircraft Factory could handle final assembly of the drones and will develop a dedicated training center in Egypt to train staff for the operation and maintenance of the drone systems.On 18 April 2016
column14: Egypt signed a contract with France for the sale of a military telecommunications satellite after discussions between the Egyptian and French presidents and between the Ministers of Defence
column15: which took place during a visit by French President Francois Hollande to Cairo. The satellite will be supplied by Airbus Defence and Space and Thales Alenia Space. The price of the contract wasn't announced but is estimated at around 600 million euros.In December 2015
column16: Russian Helicopters agreed to provide after-sales service and maintenance for the Egyptian Air Force's fleet of 41 Mi-8Ts and 3 Mi-17-1V helicopters in Russia. Under the agreement
column17: the Egyptian repair plant at Helwan Factory (HFDI)
column18: an enterprise owned by the Arab Organization for Industrialization
column19: will be authorized as an aircraft repair plant able to carry out comprehensive repairs to Mi-8T
column20: Mi-17-1V and Mi-17V-5 helicopters operated in Egypt. In order to support repair work to the frames
column22: gears and rotor systems in the helicopters
column23: the company will deliver equipment for the production line
column24: provide design and technical support and transfer all the necessary documentation to the Egyptian side for a two-year period. Egyptian specialists will be trained to carry out such repairs at the company's Novosibirsk Aircraft Repair Plant.In September 2016
column25: Russian Helicopters delivered the first 3 refurbished Mi-8T helicopters to the Egyptian Air Force after a major overhaul. The company also announced that the necessary equipment for the retooling and upgrading of the Helwan Factory aircraft repair plant had been prepared for shipment and that the Egyptian service technicians had completed training.In August 2019
column26: the Royal Jordanian Air Force transferred two of its Ilyushin Il-76MF aircraft to the Egyptian Air Force. The two aircraft are unique because they are the only stretched version of the famous Il-76 air-frame.

column1: Egypt is in an advanced stage of negotiations for the purchase of the Russian strategic air lifter Il-76MD-90A. The first export contracts of the aircraft were to be signed within 4–6 months after the MAKS-2015 air show.In 2014
column2: Egypt planned to sign a large arms deal with Russia for the purchase of 24 MiG-35 fighter jets. In February 2015
column3: MiG Director General Sergei Korotkov announced that the company was ready to supply the MiG-35 jets to Egypt should the country request them. However
column4: in April 2015
column5: Egypt signed a $2 billion contract for the purchase of 46 MiG-29M/M2 multi-role fighters instead In 2019 Egypt signed another deal for 50 MiG-35 Jets.

column1: Rosoboronexport and the Russian Helicopters holding are engaged in consultations with their Egyptian partners concerning a possible acquisition of Kamov Ka-52K ship-based helicopters for the 2 Mistral-class helicopter carriers that Egypt has agreed to buy from France. An Egyptian Air Force delegation had access to the helicopter before the official opening of the MAKS-2015.In March 2019
column2: it was reported that Egypt had reached an initial agreement with Russia for the sale of "over 20" Su-35 air superiority fighters in a deal valued at about US$2 billion. Deliveries are expected to begin as early as 2020 or 2021. However
column3: deputy head of the Rosoboronexport Sergei Kornev denied any contract regarding the supply of Su-35 fighters to Egypt has been signed. In May 2020 Russia reportedly started producing the Su-35 under a contract with Egypt that was signed in 2018. Pictures taken in July 2020 reportedly show five Su-35 in EAF camouflage on their delivery voyage. Possible future orders for more Su-35 and the new Mig-35

column1: The Roundel of the EAF consists of three circles
column2: with the outside one being red
column3: the middle one white
column4: and the inner one being black
column5: matching the Egyptian flag. Former roundels of the EAF included a similar variant with two green stars used from 1961 to 1973
column6: and one with the old Egyptian crescent and three stars on a green background. Changes in markings reflect political changes.
